raw_response: {"answer_index": 1, "answer_text": "Lumbar disc herniation", "confidence": 9, "reasoning": "The clinical presentation is classic for lumbar disc herniation: young patient with unilateral radicular pain (right leg), markedly positive straight leg raise test on affected side (20° vs 70° on left - normal is >60-70°), pain in L5 distribution, and preserved motor strength and reflexes. The severely limited SLRT on the right indicates nerve root tension/compression. Lumbar muscle tendinitis would not cause radicular symptoms or positive SLRT. Tumor and spondylolisthesis are less likely given the acute presentation and classic findings.", "evidence_quality": "normal"}
